abstract.p: Mitochondrial dysfunction is increasingly recognized as a pivotal driver of cardiomyocyte apoptosis and cardiac deterioration following myocardial infarction (MI). This study identifies a significant upregulation of DDX60 in cardiomyocytes under hypoxic conditions. Elevated DDX60 levels enhance mitochondrial function and attenuate cardiomyocyte apoptosis in vitro, whereas its knockdown induces the opposite effects. In vivo, cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 knockout markedly exacerbates mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis, accelerating post-MI cardiac remodeling and functional decline. Furthermore, we found that Arl2 knockdown partially negates the protective effects of DDX60 overexpression on ATP production and apoptosis. Conversely, adeno-associated virus-9 (AAV9)-mediated Arl2 overexpression partially restores cardiac function, reduces infarct size, and rescues mitochondrial integrity in DDX60 CKO mice post-MI. Mechanistically, DDX60 forms a translational complex with eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4 gamma 1 (EIF4G1) that enhances Arl2 mRNA translation, a process essential for mitochondrial homeostasis. Collectively, these findings establish DDX60 as a key regulator of cardioprotection post-MI by enhancing Arl2 translation, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target for ischemic heart disease.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Myocardial infarction (MI) remains a leading cause of global morbidity and mortality, characterized by acute coronary artery occlusion, ischemic cardiomyocyte death, and adverse ventricular remodeling. Whereas reperfusion therapies substantially improve clinical outcomes, residual mortality persists because of irreversible myocardial damage and progressive heart failure (HF) [1]. Mitochondrial dysfunction is central to this pathogenesis, which drives cardiomyocyte apoptosis, the predominant form of programmed cell death in ischemic myocardium [2]. Mitochondrial permeability transition pore opening, cytochrome c release, and downstream caspase-3 activation trigger a cascade of apoptotic signaling, exacerbating myocardial injury [3–5]. Despite advances in pharmacological and interventional strategies, targeted interventions aimed at mitochondrial preservation in the infarcted heart remain limited. This drawback necessitates identifying novel molecular regulators of cardiomyocyte survival.

Mitochondria serve as the cellular powerhouses responsible for generating 90% of cardiac adenosine triphosphate (ATP); they regulate calcium homeostasis, redox balance, and apoptosis [6–8]. Emerging evidence implicates mitochondrial dysfunction as a central mechanism underlying ischemia/reperfusion injury, characterized by impaired oxidative phosphorylation, excess reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and mPTP-driven apoptotic cascades [9]. Notably, the small GTPase ADP-ribosylation factor-like 2 (Arl2) has emerged as a key regulator of mitochondrial function. This evolutionarily conserved protein localizes to the mitochondrial matrix, where it facilitates oxidative phosphorylation complex assembly and ATP synthase activity [10]. Preclinical studies demonstrate that Arl2 deficiency exacerbates mitochondrial fragmentation in obesity-induced cardiomyopathy [11], whereas its downregulation aggravates pyroptosis in atrial fibrillation [12]. Furthermore, transcriptomic analyses have implicated Arl2 as a pivotal mediator in dilated cardiomyopathy pathogenesis [13]. Collectively, Arl2 holds promise in preserving mitochondrial integrity and cardiac function under pathological stress, highlighting its potential in cardiovascular disease management.

The D-E-X-H/D-box helicase family comprises ATP-dependent RNA helicases that regulate fundamental processes in RNA metabolism and protein translation [14]. Beyond their canonical roles in antiviral defense and tumorigenesis [15, 16], these enzymes have been increasingly implicated in cardiovascular pathophysiology. For instance, DHX9 exacerbates atherosclerosis progression by promoting pro-inflammatory macrophage activation [17], whereas DDX5 regulates phenotypic switching in vascular smooth muscles [18]. Notably, multiple D-E-X-H/D-box proteins directly regulate mitochondrial processes. For instance, the ABO6-encoded D-E-X-H/D-box RNA helicase regulates mitochondrial complex I gene splicing [19], whereas DDX28 orchestrates mitoribosome assembly [20]. Hence, D-E-X-H/D-box helicases play pivotal roles in cardiovascular pathogenesis and mitochondrial homeostasis. Nonetheless, their mechanistic involvement in myocardial infarction and the regulation of mitochondrial function remains unexplored. This study focuses on DDX60, a D-E-X-H/D-box RNA helicase previously associated with innate immunity through retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) pathway activation [21]. Intriguingly, a marked upregulation of DDX60 was observed in hypoxia-exposed cardiomyocytes, a novel finding in cardiac pathophysiology. Though DDX60’s role in mitochondrial regulation remains unexplored, its structural homology to other mitochondrial helicases suggests potential involvement in organelle homeostasis.

In this study, a novel mitochondrial regulatory axis involving DDX60 and Arl2 was identified. Hypoxia-induced DDX60 expression preserves mitochondrial architecture and bioenergetics in cardiomyocytes. Mechanistically, DDX60 forms a translational complex with eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4 gamma 1 (EIF4G1) that enhances Arl2 mRNA translation. This axis maintains mitochondrial membrane potential and ATP production. Cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 deletion exacerbates post-MI ventricular remodeling, whereas Arl2 supplementation restores mitochondrial function and improves survival. These findings establish DDX60 as a master regulator of mitochondrial proteostasis, offering novel therapeutic insights into ischemic cardiomyopathy treatment.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium (DMEM), fetal bovine serum (FBS), phosphate buffered saline (PBS), trypsin/ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), and penicillin/streptomycin were purchased from Gibco (Grand Island, NY, USA); anti-Flag affinity gel was puechased form Bimake (USA); BCA assay kit, 2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) solution, 2-(4-Amidinophenyl)−6-indolecarbamidine dihydrochloride (DAPI) solution, Magnetic Agarose Beads, IDA-Ni Magnetic Agarose Beads, and ATP Assay Kit were purchased from Beyotime (China); SYBR RT-PCR Kit and DNA PCR kit were from Takara Bio Inc. The following primary antibodies were used in the present study: anti-DDX60 (Ab139807, Abcam, USA), anti-Cleaved Caspase-3 (9661S, Cell Signaling Technology, USA), anti-Cleaved PARP (5625T, Cell Signaling Technology, USA), anti-GAPDH (2118S, CST), anti-β-Tubulin (2146S, Cell Signaling Technology, USA), Anti-Arl2 (A2830, Abclone, China), anti-Col3a1 (A0817, Abclone, China), anti-α-SMA (A7248, Abclone, China), anti-EIF4G1 (Sc-133155, Santa Cruz, USA), anti-Flag (CL750-20543, Proteintech, China). sec.title: Generation of cardiomyocyte-specific knockout of DDX60 mice
sec.p: Mice were housed in a pathogen-free, temperature-controlled environment with a humidity of 55% ± 10% under a 12-hour light/dark cycle. DDX60flox/flox (DDX60fl/fl) and α-myosin heavy chain (αMHC)-Cre (Cre) mice were obtained from Gempharmatech Co., Ltd. To generate cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 knockout mice, homozygous floxed DDX60 (DDX60fl/fl) mice were crossed with αMHC-Cre transgenic mice. The initial breeding produced offspring heterozygous for the floxed DDX60 allele and hemizygous for αMHC-Cre, which were subsequently bred with DDX60fl/fl mice to yield DDX60 knockout (KO) mice. Genotyping was performed via PCR, and gene deletion was validated by Western blot. DDX60fl/fl mice served as wild-type (WT) controls. The presence of the αMHC-Cre allele was confirmed using the forward primer 5′-CCTGCTGTCCATTCCTTATTCCATA-3′ and reverse primer 5′-ATATCCCCTTGTTCCCTTTCTGC-3′, yielding a 329 bp amplicon. The DDX60fl/fl allele was verified with specific primers: 3’arm Sense 5’- CATCGCATTGTCTGAGTAGGTG-3’ and 3’arm Antisense 5’-CCTGCTCTGAAATACGAGGCAA-3’, producing a 440 bp fragment. PCR conditions were as follows: 94 °C for 2 min, followed by 35 cycles of 94 °C for 30 s, 62 °C for 1 min, 72 °C for 1 min, and a final extension at 72 °C for 3 min.

sec.title: Murine model of myocardial infarction (MI)
sec.p: Eight-week-old male mice of various genotypes underwent either MI or sham surgery. Following intubation, anesthesia was induced with 2% isoflurane, and body temperature was maintained using heat lamps. MI was induced by ligating the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, whereas sham-operated mice underwent the identical procedure without LAD ligation. At predetermined time points, mice were euthanized, and organs were harvested for further analysis.

sec.title: Primary mouse neonatal cardiomyocytes isolated, culture and treatment
sec.p: Primary neonatal mouse cardiomyocytes (NMCMs) were isolated from male and female C57BL/6 mice at postnatal days 1 to 3 per established protocols [22]. To ensure the purity of NMCMs, two consecutive rounds of differential adhesion were utilized to avoid contaminating non-myocyte cardiac cells such as fibroblasts and endothelial cells. NMCMs were plated in 6-well plates and maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% penicillin/streptomycin under a 5% CO2 atmosphere at 37 °C with 95% humidity. On day 3, spontaneous rhythmic beating of the NMCMs was observed, Upon reaching ~ 80% confluence, cells were transduced with recombinant adenoviruses or their respective negative controls according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Infection efficiency was verified by Western blot. Hypoxic stress was induced by incubating NMCMs in a hypoxia chamber (1% O2, 5% CO2, 94% N2) for 24 h at 37 °C, while normoxic conditions served as controls.

sec.title: Myocardial infarct size measurement
sec.p: Myocardial infarct size was quantified using TTC staining. Harvested myocardial tissue was flash-frozen at − 30 °C for 25 min, sectioned transversely into 2-mm slices, and incubated in 2% TTC solution at 37 °C in the dark for 30 min. Infarcted areas appeared white to pale, contrasting with the dark red viable myocardium. Infarct size was analyzed using ImageJ software.

sec.title: Echocardiography
sec.p: Cardiac function was evaluated via transthoracic echocardiography 28 days post-MI, following standard procedures [23]. Key parameters, including left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), left ventricular end-systolic diameter (LVIDs), left ventricular end-diastolic diameter (LVIDd), and left ventricular fractional shortening (LVFS), were measured.

sec.title: Immunofluorescence
sec.p: For immunofluorescence (IF) analysis, cardiomyocytes were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 5 min, washed three times with PBS, permeabilized with 0.3% Triton X-100 for 10 min, and blocked with 5% BSA for 2 h at room temperature. Cells were incubated overnight at 4 °C with DDX60 primary antibodies (1:200), followed by three 5-minute washes with cold PBS. Secondary antibodies were applied for 2 h in the dark, followed by three additional PBS washes. Nuclei were counterstained with DAPI for 5 min before imaging with a fluorescence microscope (Leica Microsystems GmbH, Wetzlar, Germany).

sec.title: Flow cytometry
sec.p: For the detection of cell apoptosis, a fluorescein isothiocyanate/propidium iodide apoptosis detection kit was used. Briefly, NMCMs were trypsinized, washed twice with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, and resuspended in 500 µl of pre-cooled binding buffer. Cells were stained with Annexin V-FITC and PI per the manufacturer’s protocols. Finally, flow cytometry quantified the proportion of apoptotic cells using a MoFlo™ XDP system (Beckman Coulter, Brea, CA, USA). Each experiment was performed in triplicate, and data are reported as means ± SD.

sec.title: TUNEL assay
sec.p: Cell and tissue apoptosis was assessed using TUNEL staining according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Cardiomyocytes cultured in 12-well plates were fixed with 4% formaldehyde for 10 min, washed three times with cold PBS, and permeabilized with 0.3% Triton X-100 for 15 min. Following a 60-minute incubation with TUNEL working solution at 37 °C, cells were washed again and counterstained with DAPI for 5 min at room temperature. For in vivo analysis, myocardial tissue was harvested 72 h post-AMI, rinsed with PBS, and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde overnight at 4 °C. Fixed tissue was paraffin-embedded, sectioned to 5 μm thickness, deparaffinized, rehydrated, and subjected to antigen retrieval. Sections were then incubated with TUNEL staining solution at 37 °C in the dark for 1 h, followed by DAPI counterstaining. Apoptotic cells were quantified using fluorescence microscopy, and the apoptotic index was determined with ImageJ software.

sec.title: Measurement of Cellular ATP
sec.p: Cellular ATP levels were measured using a luciferin-luciferase assay kit following the manufacturer’s protocol. Protein extraction was performed on ATP measurement samples, with protein content determined for normalization relative to cell count or heart tissue mass.

sec.title: MTT assay
sec.p: Cell viability was assessed using the MTT assay kit. NMCMs seeded in 96-well plates (5000 cells/well) were cultured for 36 h before infection with Ad-shArl2 or control adenoviruses for an additional 36 h. MTT solution was then added, and after a 3-hour incubation, dimethyl sulfoxide was introduced to dissolve the formazan crystals. Absorbance was measured at 490 nm using a microplate reader (Molecular Devices, Silicon Valley, CA, USA).

sec.title: Western blot analysis
sec.p: Protein expression levels were analyzed using Western blot. Myocardial and cellular proteins were extracted using RIPA buffer supplemented with 1% PMSF. Protein concentrations were quantified using a BCA assay kit. Samples were resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE and transferred onto PVDF membranes. After blocking with 5% BSA for 2 h, membranes were incubated overnight at 4 °C with primary antibodies against DDX60, Cleaved Caspase-3, Cleaved PARP, Arl2, Col3a1, α-SMA, EIF4G1, Flag, GAPDH, and β-Tubulin. Secondary antibody incubation was performed at room temperature for 2 h. Protein bands were visualized using an ECL detection system, and densitometric analysis was conducted with ImageJ software.

sec.title: RNA extraction and Quantitative real-time PCR
Histopathological examination
sec.p: At 28 days post-MI, heart tissues were collected, fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde overnight at 4 °C, embedded in paraffin, sectioned into 5-µm slices using a microtome, and mounted on glass slides. After baking, sections were deparaffinized, rehydrated, and subjected to hematoxylin and eosin (H&E, Solarbio) staining for 10 min. Additional histological assessments included Masson’s trichrome and Picrosirius Red staining. Myocardial histopathology was examined using light microscopy.

sec.title: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
sec.p: Mitochondrial morphology was evaluated via TEM. Briefly, at 24 h post-MI, myocardial tissues were trimmed into 1-mm3 fragments and fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde for 24 h. Standard dehydration, embedding, and polymerization procedures were performed, followed by ultrathin sectioning (50–100 nm). Sections were stained with uranyl acetate and lead citrate and subsequently imaged using TEM.

sec.title: DHE staining and MitoSOX staining
sec.p: Myocardial reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels were quantified using DHE. Freshly harvested myocardial tissue was flash-frozen at − 30 °C for 25 min, sectioned into 10-µm slices, and incubated with 3 µM DHE at 37 °C for 30 min before fluorescence microscopy analysis. Mitochondrial ROS was assessed using MitoSOX following the manufacturer’s protocol. Images were captured with a fluorescence microscope and processed using ImageJ.

Mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψm) in NMCMs was assessed using the JC-1 probe. NMCMs were incubated with 2 µg/mL JC-1 at 37 °C for 20 min in the dark, washed three times with cold PBS, and imaged using fluorescence microscopy. A shift in JC-1 fluorescence from green (525 nm) to red (590 nm) indicated mitochondrial polarization, whereas a reduction in the red: green fluorescence intensity ratio reflected Δψm dissipation.

sec.title: Glutathione S-transferase (GST) pull-down
sec.p: Recombinant plasmids encoding human DDX60 with a GST tag and human EIF4G with a His tag were designed and constructed by MIAOLING Biology. Plasmids were transformed into E. coli BL21, and single colonies were selected from Luria-Bertani (LB) plates for large-scale culture in LB medium at 37 °C. Protein expression was induced with 0.4 mM IPTG overnight at 20 °C. Proteins were purified using a GST-Tag Protein Purification Kit with Magnetic Agarose Beads and a His-Tag Protein Purification Kit with IDA-Ni Magnetic Agarose Beads. Protein-protein interactions were analyzed using a GST Pull-Down Kit following the manufacturer’s protocol. SDS-PAGE and Western blot were performed to confirm the interaction between EIF4G and DDX60.

sec.title: Mitochondrial oxygen consumption rate (OCR)
sec.p: Mitochondrial respiration was evaluated using the Agilent Seahorse XFp Analyzer (Santa Clara, CA, USA) to determine the OCR. NMCMs were seeded in XF96 cell culture microplates at a density of 105 cells/well and cultured in a complete growth medium at 37 °C with 5% CO2 for 48 h. On the first day, the XFp Sensor Cartridge was hydrated with ultrapure water and incubated overnight in a non-CO2 incubator at 37 °C. On the second day, the culture medium was replaced with an assay medium supplemented with 10 mM glucose, 2 mM glutamine, and 1 mM pyruvate. Mitochondrial stress test compounds, including oligomycin (1 µM), FCCP (0.5 µM), and rotenone/antimycin A (0.5 µM each), were loaded into the injection ports, and the assay was performed according to the manufacturer’s protocol.

sec.title: Mass spectrometer
sec.p: HEK293T cells were transfected with Flag-tagged DDX60 expression vectors or control plasmids using Lipofectamine 3000 and incubated for 48 h. Post-transfection, cells were lysed in IP lysis buffer, and lysates were immunoprecipitated using an anti-Flag affinity gel. Immunoprecipitated proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE, followed by tryptic digestion and mass spectrometry-based peptide identification and interaction analysis, conducted by Applied Protein Technology Co., Ltd. Detailed mass spectrometry parameters, including the instrument model, ionization mode, and data acquisition methods, were described previously [24].

sec.title: Co-Immunoprecipitations assay analyses
sec.p: NMCMs were lysed in a buffer containing 20 mM Tris (pH 7.5), 150 mM NaCl, 0.3% Triton X-100, and 1× Roche phosphatase and protease inhibitors, followed by collection via scraping. Lysates were incubated on ice for 30 min, transferred to fresh tubes, and centrifuged at 11,000 g for 15 min. Approximately 600 µg of total protein was incubated with antibodies against DDX60 or EIF4G1 conjugated to Protein A/G magnetic beads at 4 °C for 5 h under constant rotation. Beads were washed four times with 600 µL of lysis buffer and eluted in Laemmli buffer at 100 °C for 5 min.

sec.title: Proteomics
sec.p: Cardiomyocytes were cultured in 10-cm dishes for 24 h, followed by infection with AdshDDX60 or its negative control for another 24 h. Each group comprised three 10-cm dishes. Subsequently, cells were exposed to hypoxic conditions for 24 h, collected, lysed, and analyzed using a timsTOF Pro mass spectrometer (Bruker) coupled with an Evosep One liquid chromatography system (Denmark). Peptide identification, interaction protein analysis, and bioinformatics assessments were performed by Applied Protein Technology Co., Ltd. Differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) in AdshDDX60-infected and control groups were identified based on |log2 (fold change)| >1 and p ≤ 0.05. Detailed mass spectrometry parameters, including the instrument model and ionization mode, were described previously [25].

sec.title: RNA immunoprecipitation (RIP)
sec.p: RIP was performed using the Magna RIP Kit following the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, NMCMs were lysed in RIP buffer, and 5 µg of anti-DDX60 (or anti-Flag) antibody, or anti-rabbit IgG (negative control), was incubated with 50 µL of magnetic beads at 4 °C overnight. The RNA-antibody-magnetic bead complexes were washed five times and treated with proteinase K to release RNA-bound proteins. RNA was extracted using phenol-chloroform and analyzed by qPCR. Target regions were quantified relative to input controls and normalized against IgG controls.

sec.title: DNA agarose gel electrophoresis
sec.p: DNA agarose gel electrophoresis was performed as described previously [26]. Briefly, 1.5% agarose gels were prepared using agarose from Sangon Biotech and electrophoresed at 140 V for 30 min in 1 × TBE buffer. Gels were stained with Ultra GelRed and visualized under UV light. Images were captured and processed using Photoshop.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data are presented as mean ± SD. Statistical analyses were conducted using GraphPad Prism 8. Two-group comparisons were performed using Student’s t-test, while one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s post hoc test was applied for multiple-group comparisons. Survival analysis was assessed using the log-rank test, with p < 0.05 considered statistically significant.

p.bold: DDX60 remarkably alleviated cardiomyocyte apoptosis upon hypoxia stimuli

list-item.p:
To investigate whether DDX60 regulates cardiomyocyte apoptosis under hypoxia, a time-course experiment was conducted using NMCMs exposed to hypoxia for 0, 12, and 24 h. Western blotting indicated a progressive increase in DDX60 expression at 12 h, which was significantly upregulated at 24 h (Fig. 1A–C), suggesting its potential involvement in cardiomyocyte apoptosis regulation. To further confirm its functional role, DDX60 expression was silenced or overexpressed using adenoviral vectors, with successful transduction confirmed by Western blotting (Fig. S1A–C). Interestingly, DDX60 overexpression significantly reduced apoptosis after 24 h of hypoxia, as indicated by decreased cleaved PARP and cleaved caspase-3 (Fig. 1D–F). In contrast, DDX60 knockdown reversed this effect, highlighting its protective action (Fig. 1G–I). Meanwhile, flow cytometry and TUNEL staining further evaluated the effects of DDX60 on cardiomyocyte apoptosis. Ad–shDDX60–infected NMCMs demonstrated an increase in the percentage of apoptotic cells after hypoxic exposure. However, NMCMs overexpressing DDX60 (Ad-D60 group) demonstrated significantly decreased apoptosis, compared with negative control (Ad-NC) cells (Fig. 1J–K and Fig. S1D-E). Taken together, these observations suggest that DDX60 alleviates cardiomyocyte apoptosis upon hypoxia stimuli.Fig. 1

Cardiomyocyte-specific knockout of DDX60 aggravated cardiomyocyte apoptosis and promoted cardiac dysfunction in the acute phase of MI.

To further elucidate the role of DDX60 in vivo, a cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 knockout (DDX60 CKO) mouse model was generated by crossing α-MHC-Cre mice with DDX60fl/fl mice, leading to the deletion of exons 5–9 in cardiomyocytes (Cre+). DDX60fl/fl littermates (Cre−) served as WT controls (Fig. S2A). PCR analysis of genomic DNA confirmed successful Cre/loxP-mediated recombination in cardiomyocyte-specific knockout mice (Fig. S2B), while Western blot revealed markedly reduced DDX60 protein levels in the hearts of DDX60 CKO mice compared to WT and DDX60fl/fl controls (Fig. S2C–D). Despite this genetic deletion, DDX60 CKO mice exhibited normal growth, lifespan, and no apparent signs of cardiac hypertrophy or fibrosis under baseline conditions (Fig. S2E–G).

At two months of age, mice underwent MI surgery, and echocardiographic assessments were performed on days 1 and 7 post-MI. No significant differences in cardiac function were observed between the two genotypes at day 1. However, by day 7 post-MI, DDX60 CKO mice exhibited significantly impaired cardiac function compared to WT controls, characterized by reduced ejection fraction and fractional shortening, along with increased end-systolic and end-diastolic ventricular dimensions (Fig. 2A–E). Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining performed on day 3 post-MI revealed a markedly larger infarct size in DDX60 CKO mice compared to WT controls (Fig. 2F–G). Consistently, Western blot analyses of apoptosis-related proteins (cleaved caspase-3 and cleaved PARP) and TUNEL staining confirmed a significant increase in cardiomyocyte apoptosis in DDX60 knockout mice (Fig. 2H–L), as evidenced by elevated apoptotic marker expression and a higher percentage of TUNEL-positive cells relative to WT littermates. Collectively, these results demonstrate that cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 deletion exacerbates apoptosis and worsens cardiac function in the acute phase of MI.Fig. 2

p.bold: Cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 deletion aggravates cardiac dysfunction and myocardial fibrosis in the healing phase of MI

list-item.p:
Following acute MI, infarcted myocardial tissue induces profound alterations in ventricular geometry, characterized by infarct thinning and compensatory hypertrophy of viable myocardium [27], both of which critically affect cardiac function. Accordingly, echocardiographic assessment at 28 days post-MI revealed that DDX60 CKO mice exhibited significantly reduced ejection fraction (EF) and fractional shortening (FS), along with markedly enlarged end-systolic and end-diastolic ventricular dimensions compared to control littermates (Fig. 3A-E). Cardiac fibrosis was quantified in transverse heart sections stained with Masson’s trichrome, demonstrating a substantial increase in total collagen content in DDX60 CKO mice relative to controls (Fig. 3F-G). To further delineate this disparity, collagen deposition was assessed across different cardiac regions, revealing significantly denser collagen accumulation in the infarct zones at both papillary and apical levels in DDX60 CKO hearts compared to DDX60fl/fl hearts (Fig. S3A-E). Additionally, Picrosirius red staining under polarized light showed densely packed, thick, and highly organized collagen fibers in the infarcted myocardium of DDX60 CKO hearts at 28 days post-MI, whereas control littermates exhibited relatively sparse and disorganized fibers (Fig. S3F-G). Western blot analysis of fibrosis-associated proteins further substantiated these observations, as DDX60 knockout led to significantly elevated expression of α-SMA and Col3a1, indicating exacerbated fibrotic remodeling post-MI (Fig. 3H-J). Consistently, survival rates at four weeks post-MI were lower in DDX60 CKO mice than in controls (38.9% vs. 62.5%) (Fig. 3K). Morphological analysis further revealed significantly increased heart weight-to-body weight and lung weight-to-body weight ratios in DDX60 CKO mice compared to DDX60fl/fl controls, underscoring the severity of congestive HF and pulmonary edema in the absence of DDX60 (Fig. 3L-M and Fig. S3H-I). Collectively, these results establish that DDX60 deficiency in cardiomyocytes exacerbates post-MI cardiac remodeling.Fig. 3

p.bold: DDX60 overexpression ameliorates hypoxia/MI-induced mitochondrial injury

list-item.p:
Mitochondrial dysfunction is a principal driver of cardiomyocyte apoptosis following ischemic injury [2]. To investigate the role of DDX60 in mitochondrial regulation, JC-1 staining was performed to assess mitochondrial membrane potential. Hypoxia-induced depolarization of the mitochondrial membrane potential, evidenced by an increased JC-1 green fluorescence signal, was significantly exacerbated by DDX60 inhibition, whereas DDX60 overexpression mitigated this effect (Fig. 4A-B).Fig. 4

Scale bars: 50 μm. B The histogram represents the ratio of JC-1 red to green fluorescence (Red/Green) (n = 5 per group). C Measurement of cardiomyocyte OCR across different groups. D Mitochondrial function parameters, including basal respiration, ATP production-coupled respiration, and maximal oxygen consumption capacity, derived from OCR data in (C). E Detection of ROS production using a MitoSOX probe. Scale bars: 50 μm. F Quantification of ROS levels in the indicated groups (n = 5 per group). G-H Representative fluorescence microscopy images and quantification of superoxide anion levels using DHE staining in heart tissues from WT and DDX60 CKO mice under sham and 1-day post-MI conditions (n = 5 per group). Statistical analyses were conducted using one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s post hoc test. *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01, ***P < 0.001, ns = not significant

Mitochondrial respiratory function was further evaluated by measuring OCR at different time points. Hypoxia-induced reductions in basal respiration, ATP production-coupled respiration, and maximal mitochondrial oxygen consumption capacity were markedly aggravated by DDX60 inhibition but significantly restored upon DDX60 overexpression (Fig. 4C-D). The impact of DDX60 on oxidative stress was assessed using MitoSOX Red staining. Fluorescence microscopy revealed a substantial increase in ROS production following hypoxia, which was further exacerbated by DDX60 inhibition but significantly attenuated by DDX60 overexpression (Fig. 4E-F). Consistently, in vivo DHE staining demonstrated that DDX60 knockout led to heightened ROS accumulation in the peri-infarct zone (Fig. 4G-H). To further elucidate the role of DDX60 in mitochondrial integrity, TEM was utilized to examine mitochondrial ultrastructure. TEM imaging revealed that ischemic injury resulted in severe mitochondrial swelling and cristae disruption, with DDX60 knockout further exacerbating cristae disorganization and the presence of vacuolated mitochondria (Fig. 4I-J). Collectively, these results establish that DDX60 exerts a cardioprotective role by preserving mitochondrial structure and function, thereby mitigating ischemia-induced mitochondrial abnormalities in MI.

p.bold: DDX60 is co-located with EIF4G in the cardiomyocytes

list-item.p:
To elucidate the cardioprotective mechanism of DDX60, mass spectrometry was performed to identify potential interacting targets, revealing 73 proteins with an iBAQ FLAG_DDX60/iBAQ IgG ratio ≥ 1.5 (Table S1). However, no mitochondrial protection-related candidates were identified within the dataset. A further search in the BioGRID database (https://thebiogrid.org/120742/summary/homo-sapiens/ddx60.html) similarly failed to yield relevant mitochondrial protective proteins. Subsequently, Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis (Fig. S4) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway analysis (Fig. S5) were conducted to determine biological processes associated with DDX60. Notably, the identified interacting proteins were predominantly involved in the early stages of protein synthesis, including translational initiation, cytoplasmic translation initiation complex formation, translational regulation, viral translation termination-reinitiation, and internal ribosome entry site (IRES)-dependent viral translational initiation (Table S2 and Fig. 5A). Venn diagram analysis of overlapping proteins from both databases identified three candidates: EIF3G, EIF4G1, and STAU1 (Fig. 5B). Given the pivotal role of EIF4G1 in eukaryotic translation initiation, AlphaFold3 was employed to predict its interaction with DDX60. The predicted interface pTM and ipTM scores were 0.54 and 0.33, respectively (Fig. 5C), suggesting a potential direct interaction. To validate this interaction, IF staining and co-immunoprecipitation (Co-IP) assays were performed. IF staining in NMCMs demonstrated co-localization of DDX60 and EIF4G1, with an overlap index of 85% and a Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.65 (Fig. 5D-E). Co-IP assays further confirmed a physical interaction between DDX60 and EIF4G1 in cultured cardiomyocytes. To exclude indirect interactions mediated by additional factors, a glutathione-S-transferase (GST) pull-down assay was conducted, demonstrating direct binding between purified recombinant His-EIF4G1 and GST-DDX60 proteins in vitro (Fig. 5F-G). Collectively, these results indicate that DDX60 may regulate translation by directly binding with EIF4G1.Fig. 5

C Three-dimensional structure predictions of DDX60 and EIF4G1 generated using AlphaFold3 (left), with DDX60 in red and EIF4G1 in green. Predicted interaction sites between DDX60 and EIF4G1 (right). D Immunofluorescence analysis showing co-localization of EIF4G1 and DDX60 in NMCMs. E Relative scatter plots quantifying co-localization of DDX60 and EIF4G1 fluorescence signals in (D). The overlap index is 85%, and the Pearson coefficient is 0.65. p.bold: DDX60 is involved in the regulation of Arl2 mRNA translation

list-item.p:
Given the role of DDX60 in translation regulation, proteomic analysis was performed, identifying 4,438 proteins. Differential expression analysis revealed 47 significantly altered proteins (p < 0.05, |log2 fold change| >1), with 40 upregulated and 7 downregulated (Fig. 6A, Table S3). KEGG pathway analysis further indicated that DDX60 knockdown exacerbated cardiomyocyte apoptosis and heightened ROS production following 24-hour hypoxic insult (Fig. 6B, Fig. S6), consistent with experimental findings. These results reinforce the critical involvement of DDX60 in mitochondrial function regulation.Fig. 6
DDX60 regulates Arl2 mRNA translation A Heatmap from proteomic analysis illustrating differentially expressed proteins in the indicated samples. B KEGG pathway analysis highlighting enriched biological processes in cardiomyocytes infected with shDDX60 (sh-D60) or negative control (NC) under hypoxic conditions. C Representative Western blot and quantitative analysis of Arl2 expression in NC- and sh-D60-treated NMCMs (n = 5 per group). D Representative Western blot and quantitative analysis of Arl2 expression in heart tissues from WT and DDX60 CKO mice (n = 5 per group). E RT-qPCR analysis of Arl2 mRNA expression in DDX60-knockdown NMCMs and DDX60 knockout mice (n = 5 per group). F Representative Western blot and quantitative analysis of Arl2 expression in NC- and sh-EIF4G1-treated NMCMs (n = 5 per group). G RT-qPCR analysis of Arl2 and EIF4G1 mRNA levels in EIF4G1-knockdown NMCMs (n = 5 per group). H RIP assay detecting Arl2 mRNA in cardiomyocyte samples immunoprecipitated with an anti-DDX60 antibody or control IgG. All data are presented as mean ± SD from at least five independent biological experiments. Statistical significance was determined using an unpaired two-tailed Student’s t-test. ***P < 0.001, ns = not significant

Differential expression analysis between Ad-shDDX60 and Ad-shNC groups identified Arl2, a key regulator of mitochondrial homeostasis and ATP production in cardiomyocytes [28], as significantly downregulated in DDX60-knockdown cells under hypoxia. Western blot analysis validated the proteomic findings, revealing a pronounced reduction in Arl2 protein levels in DDX60-knockdown cardiomyocytes even in the absence of hypoxic insult (Fig. 6C). Similarly, Arl2 expression was markedly reduced in cardiomyocyte-specific DDX60 knockout heart tissues under baseline conditions (Fig. 6D). Notably, despite the substantial decrease in Arl2 protein levels, its mRNA expression remained unchanged in both DDX60-knockdown cardiomyocytes and DDX60 CKO heart tissues (Fig. 6E), suggesting that DDX60 primarily regulates Arl2 at the translational level. Given the established interaction between DDX60 and EIF4G1, the role of EIF4G1 in Arl2 regulation was further investigated. EIF4G1 knockdown resulted in a significant reduction in Arl2 protein levels, while its mRNA expression remained unaffected (Fig. 6F-G), reinforcing the notion that DDX60 and EIF4G1 jointly regulate Arl2 translation. To assess whether DDX60 interacts with Arl2 mRNA, RNA-Protein Interaction Prediction (RPISeq) analysis was performed. The support vector machine (SVM) and random forest (RF) classifiers yielded prediction scores of 0.83 and 0.65, respectively, indicating a high probability of interaction. RIP assays in NMCMs further confirmed this interaction, demonstrating significant enrichment of Arl2 mRNA in the DDX60-antibody group compared to the IgG control (Fig. 6H). Collectively, these results suggest that DDX60 and EIF4G1 cooperatively regulate Arl2 expression by facilitating its translation.

p.bold: Arl2 is the underlying target mediating the cardioprotective roles of DDX60

list-item.p:
To determine whether Arl2 mediates the cardioprotective effects of DDX60, its expression was first examined in cardiomyocytes following hypoxic stimulation. Both mRNA and protein levels of Arl2 were markedly upregulated under hypoxia (Fig. S7A-C). Further investigation revealed that DDX60 overexpression significantly increased Arl2 protein levels without affecting its mRNA expression, reinforcing the role of DDX60 in the translational regulation of Arl2 (Fig. 7A-C). To elucidate the biological function of Arl2, adenoviral vectors were used to manipulate its expression in NMCMs, with overexpression and knockdown efficiency confirmed by Western blot analysis. Notably, Arl2 overexpression significantly reduced cardiomyocyte apoptosis following hypoxic injury, as indicated by decreased levels of cleaved Caspase-3 and cleaved PARP, whereas Arl2 knockdown had the opposite effect (Fig. S7D-K). The impact of Arl2 on energy metabolism was further examined. Consistent with previous findings [28], Arl2 knockdown significantly reduced cellular ATP levels under normoxic conditions (Fig. S7L) without affecting cell viability (Fig. S7M). Moreover, Arl2 overexpression partially reversed ATP depletion in NMCMs under hypoxic conditions (Fig. S7N), highlighting its cardioprotective role.Fig. 7

D-F Representative Western blot and quantitative analysis of cleaved-PARP and cleaved-caspase3 expression in the indicated groups (n = 5 per group). G Representative TUNEL staining (upper) and ROS production detected using a MitoSOX probe (lower) in the indicated groups. Scale bar: 40 μm. H Quantification of TUNEL-positive cells as a percentage of total cells in each group. I Quantification of ROS production in the indicated groups (n = 5 per group). J ATP assay demonstrating that DDX60 knockdown exacerbates ATP depletion in hypoxia-exposed cardiomyocytes, whereas DDX60 overexpression enhances ATP content (n = 5 per group). K Arl2 knockdown partially reverses the effects of DDX60 overexpression on ATP production in hypoxia-exposed cardiomyocytes (n = 5 per group). L Representative transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of cardiomyocytes in the indicated groups. Scale bar: 0.5 μm. M Quantification of the proportion of mitochondria exhibiting disorganized cristae in the indicated groups (n = 5 per group). All data are presented as mean ± SD from at least five independent biological experiments. Statistical significance was determined using one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s post hoc test. *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01, ***P < 0.001, ns = not significant

To assess whether Arl2 is required for DDX60-mediated cardioprotection, NMCMs were co-transfected with Ad-DDX60 and Ad-shArl2 for 24 h, followed by hypoxic treatment for another 24 h. Notably, Arl2 knockdown partially abrogated the protective effects of DDX60 overexpression, resulting in increased apoptosis marker expression (cleaved Caspase-3 and cleaved PARP), a higher proportion of TUNEL-positive cells, enhanced ROS accumulation, decreased cellular ATP levels, and aggravated mitochondrial dysfunction compared to Ad-NC-transfected DDX60-overexpressing cardiomyocytes (Fig. 7D-M).

Furthermore, AAV9 vectors encoding the open reading frame of mouse Arl2 were constructed. At six weeks of age, DDX60 CKO mice received a tail vein injection of AAV9-cTnT-Arl2 or AAV9-cTnT-NC (3 × 1011 GC) two weeks prior to MI or sham surgery, followed by echocardiographic assessment seven days post-MI. The findings revealed that Arl2 overexpression significantly mitigated cardiac dysfunction and left ventricular dilation in DDX60 CKO mice, as evidenced by increased EF and FS alongside reduced end-systolic and end-diastolic ventricular dimensions in the AAV9-Arl2 group (Fig. 8A–E). Additionally, TEM performed one day post-MI demonstrated that Arl2 overexpression markedly attenuated MI-induced mitochondrial morphological abnormalities in the infarct border zone of DDX60 CKO mice (Fig. 8F–G). TTC staining further confirmed a significant reduction in infarct size following Arl2 overexpression compared to the AAV9-NC group (Fig. 8H–I). Consistently, Western blot analysis of apoptosis-related proteins (cleaved caspase-3 and cleaved PARP) and TUNEL staining revealed a substantial decrease in apoptosis marker expression and the percentage of TUNEL-positive cells in the AAV9-Arl2 group relative to the AAV9-NC group (Fig. 8J–P). In parallel with the results in vivo, Arl2 overexpression partially reversed the pro-apoptotic effects of DDX60 knockdown on cardiomyocyte apoptosis, as evidenced by reduced levels of cleaved PARP and cleaved caspase-3 (Fig. S8). Collectively, these results identify Arl2 as a key mediator of the cardioprotective effects of DDX60 following MI.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Mitochondrial dysfunction has emerged as a central pathogenic mechanism underlying cardiomyocyte apoptosis and subsequent heart failure after myocardial infarction. Hence, mitochondrial preservation serves as a critical therapeutic strategy in ischemic heart disease [2–4]. In this study, a novel cardioprotective function of DDX60 was identified, demonstrating its ability to mitigate mitochondrial injury by modulating Arl2 protein synthesis. A combination of biochemical and functional analyses demonstrated that DDX60 enhances Arl2 protein synthesis by forming a complex with EIF4G1 (Fig. 9). This mechanism not only expands the understanding of RNA helicase functions beyond their canonical roles in antiviral defense but also positions DDX60 as a key regulator of mitochondrial proteostasis in cardiac function.Fig. 9
Schematic representation of the cardioprotective mechanisms of DDX60 via mitochondrial enhancement and anti-apoptotic regulation Under hypoxic/ischemic conditions, myocardial DDX60 expression is markedly upregulated. Elevated DDX60 binds Arl2 mRNA and cooperates with EIF4G1 to facilitate Arl2 mRNA translation. Arl2 upregulation partially rescues ATP depletion, reduces ROS production, ameliorates mitochondrial structural and functional abnormalities in cardiomyocytes, and improves post-MI cardiac function

The D-E-X-H/D-box helicase family has been traditionally studied in RNA metabolism and antiviral responses. A growing body of evidence demonstrates its regulatory function in cardiovascular diseases. For instance, DHX9 contributes to atherosclerosis progression [17], whereas DDX5 regulates vascular remodeling [18]. The present findings elucidate DDX60’s unique ability to orchestrate mitochondrial protection, a function distinct from its role in RIG-I-mediated antiviral immunity. This functional divergence highlights the contextual specificity of helicases and necessitates investigating understudied helicase members in disease pathogenesis. DDX60 upregulation under hypoxic conditions in cardiomyocytes, coupled with its mitochondrial regulatory function, positions it as a critical stress-responsive mediator in cardiac adaptation to ischemia.

Mitochondria are cellular powerhouses that control ATP generation through oxidative phosphorylation. They orchestrate energy metabolism, calcium homeostasis, and redox regulation, all of which are fundamental processes underpinning cellular viability and apoptotic control. Aberrations in mitochondrial function have been implicated in the pathogenesis of cardiovascular disorders ranging from ischemic cardiomyopathy to atherosclerosis [29, 30]. Beyond cardiovascular contexts, environmental toxicants target mitochondrial networks through distinct mechanisms. For example, arsenic exposure drives ferroptosis via ROS accumulation [31], microplastics induce pyroptosis through membrane destabilization [32], and phthalates activate apoptosis through inflammatory cascades [33]. These events converge on mitochondrial collapse as a universal pathomechanism. The systematic analysis of DDX60’s protective role—spanning transmission electron microscopy, oxygen consumption rate assays, and hierarchical validation through Arl2 overexpression—suggests a conserved regulatory axis that counters these destructive processes. Arl2 restoration in DDX60-deficient NMCMs reverses bioenergetic defects, confirming the DDX60–Arl2 axis as a hierarchical pathway. Moreover, it positions this axis as a universal regulator of mitochondrial resilience under stress.

The mechanistic interplay between DDX60 and its molecular partners forms a tightly coordinated axis critical for cardiac recovery after ischemic injury. Through a multi-layered experimental approach—combining proteomic screening that identified EIF4G1 as a DDX60-binding protein, glutathione S-transferase pull-down assay confirming direct interaction, and RNA immunoprecipitation followed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction confirming DDX60’s association with Arl2 mRNA—a biologically relevant regulatory chain was delineated. This triad of molecular interactions positions DDX60 as a translational enhancer, leveraging EIF4G1’s canonical role in forming the eIF4F translation initiation complex. Stable Arl2 mRNA levels confirm this post-transcriptional regulation, despite protein depletion in DDX60-deficient cardiomyocytes. This finding elucidates translational control rather than transcriptional regulation as the primary mechanism. Notably, the DDX60-Arl2 axis converges on mitochondrial dynamics and cellular survival, with Arl2’s established roles in ATP synthase stabilization and cristae morphology maintaining bioenergetic integrity under hypoxia. Hence, DDX60-mediated Arl2 upregulation protects the ischemic myocardium.

Despite these substantial mechanistic insights, certain limitations merit discussion. First, translational regulation has been demonstrated using Arl2 as a target; nonetheless, further studies should use polysome profiling to delineate precise ribosome loading dynamics. Second, the exclusive use of male murine models limits the generalizability of the findings, specifically related to sex-based responses in MI pathogenesis and post-MI remodeling [34]. Third, the translational applicability of these findings necessitates future investigations using human cardiomyocyte models and pharmacological DDX60 activators. Nevertheless, this study has a few strengths. Advances in gene delivery technologies [35] and hypoxia-responsive vectors [36] may overcome therapeutic barriers, potentially enabling the targeted activation of DDX60 in ischemic tissues.

In conclusion, this study identifies DDX60 as a central mediator of mitochondrial adaptation to ischemic injury through its novel role in Arl2 translation. By bridging RNA helicase function with mitochondrial proteostasis, these findings advance the understanding of post-MI cardiac recovery and offer a novel therapeutic avenue for modulating mitochondrial resilience. The efficacy of AAV9-mediated Arl2 supplementation in rescuing DDX60-deficient phenotypes further supports the translational potential of this axis. Considering the role of mitochondrial dysfunction across several cardiovascular disorders, the DDX60-Arl2 axis holds promise as a strategy to improve clinical outcomes in ischemic heart disease and beyond.
